importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: This is the date when Nicolas Sarkozy began serving his five-year jail sentence, marking a significant political event in France.
The date corresponds to the public arrival of Sarkozy at La Sante prison, symbolizing the moment of accountability and the start of his incarceration.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The two-month period during which the court will review the release appeal, indicating that Sarkozy’s imprisonment is not final and remains subject to legal review.

keyTakeAways: Nicolas Sarkozy, former President of France, has begun a five-year prison sentence for criminal conspiracy related to illegal campaign financing from Muammar Gaddafi.
Sarkozy is the first former head of a European Union state to be jailed, making the case historically significant in European political history.
He was found guilty of accepting millions of euros in illegal payments to fund his 2007 election campaign, a violation of French electoral laws.
Sarkozy has consistently denied the charges, asserting his innocence and claiming that truth will prevail.
He will be held in solitary confinement in a 9-square-meter cell at La Sante prison, with limited contact and only one daily walk.
He will receive three weekly visits from family or legal representatives and will be allowed to keep a biography of Jesus and a copy of The Count of Monte Cristo.
The presiding judge, Nathalie Gavarino, described the offenses as of 'exceptional gravity' and ordered a jail sentence even if an appeal is filed.
The court has two months to consider the appeal filed by Sarkozy’s lawyers, indicating that his imprisonment is potentially reversible.
This case marks the first time a former French president has been imprisoned since Philippe Petain, a WWII collaborator, highlighting its rarity and gravity in French political history.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Former French President Nicolas Sarkozy has started a five-year prison sentence at La Sante prison in Paris after being found guilty of criminal conspiracy for accepting millions of euros in illegal campaign funding from Libyan leader Muammar Gaddafi in 2007. He is the first former head of a European Union state to be jailed, making the case a landmark in European political history. Despite denying the charges and filing an appeal, the presiding judge, Nathalie Gavarino, described the offenses as of 'exceptional gravity' and ruled that incarceration was mandatory. Sarkozy will be held in solitary confinement in a 9-square-meter cell, with limited contact and daily walks, and will receive three weekly visits. The court has two months to review his appeal, leaving the possibility of release open. The event has drawn public attention and emotional reactions from supporters, who expressed sorrow for what they see as a blow to democracy and the rule of law.
title: Former French president Nicolas Sarkozy starts five-year jail term
